articles.headline: Militants Said to Flee Before U.S. Offensive
articles.snippet: The second-ranking U.S. commander in Iraq said that Qaeda leaders had been alerted to a plan for an American push in Baquba.
articles.abstract: The second-ranking U.S. commander in Iraq said that Qaeda leaders had been alerted to a plan for an American push in Baquba.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, June 22 — The operational commander of troops battling to drive fighters with Al Qaeda from Baquba said Friday that 80 percent of the top Qaeda leaders in the city fled before the American-led offensive began earlier this week. He compared their flight with the escape of Qaeda leaders from Falluja ahead of an American offensive that recaptured that city in 2004.

articles.headline: A Lifeline of Sorts to Newspapers
articles.snippet: Should other media companies follow Sam Zell and the Tribune Company into ESOP-ville?
articles.abstract: Should other media companies follow Sam Zell and the Tribune Company into ESOP-ville?
articles.lead_paragraph: So I went to Chicago this week to see Sam Zell, the billionaire real estate mogul who not all that long ago sold one of his major holdings, Equity Office Properties Trust, to the Blackstone Group for $39 billion.

articles.headline: $3.2 Billion Move by Bear Stearns to Rescue Fund
articles.snippet: A hedge fund’s near collapse stems directly from bad bets on subprime mortgages and is the biggest such bailout since 1998.
articles.abstract: A hedge fund’s near collapse stems directly from bad bets on subprime mortgages and is the biggest such bailout since 1998.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bear Stearns Companies, the investment bank, pledged up to $3.2 billion in loans yesterday to bail out one of its hedge funds that was collapsing because of bad bets on subprime mortgages.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: AT&T Hoping the iPhone Has Coattails
articles.snippet: Analysts agree that the sleek iPhone will change what consumers expect from the mobile phones offered by wireless companies.
articles.abstract: Analysts agree that the sleek iPhone will change what consumers expect from the mobile phones offered by wireless companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 — When the iPhone goes on sale next Friday, people are likely to flood AT&T Wireless and Apple stores to check out the new device. But will the curiosity translate into big business for AT&T?

articles.headline: Lowering Flag for War’s Dead Brings a New Rift
articles.snippet: Orders to lower the flag, and decisions not to, are part of a conflict over how to commemorate tragedy when there is so much of it.
articles.abstract: Orders to lower the flag, and decisions not to, are part of a conflict over how to commemorate tragedy when there is so much of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., June 19 — The Stars and Stripes in front of the Veterans of Foreign Wars lodge here flies at half-staff because Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm issued a statewide order to lower the flag for 24 hours to honor a Michigan soldier killed in Iraq.

articles.headline: Keeping Early Retirees Afloat
articles.snippet: Some of the nation’s biggest companies will announce a new program meant to make health insurance available to their former employees ages 55 to 64.
articles.abstract: Some of the nation’s biggest companies will announce a new program meant to make health insurance available to their former employees ages 55 to 64.
articles.lead_paragraph: What with years of layoffs, employee buyouts and sending jobs offshore, corporate America has helped create a pool of about 800,000 early retirees who now find themselves in a health care bind.

articles.headline: Bill Is Offered to Increase Tax on Private Equity
articles.snippet: Leading Democrats introduced legislation that would more than double taxes on most of the income earned by partnerships.
articles.abstract: Leading Democrats introduced legislation that would more than double taxes on most of the income earned by partnerships.
articles.lead_paragraph: Interest on Capitol Hill in raising taxes on private equity and hedge fund managers reached a peak yesterday as leading Democrats introduced a bill that would more than double taxes on most of the income earned by partnerships, including private equity managers, venture capitalists and some hedge funds.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: A Long Line for a Shorter Wait at the Supermarket
articles.snippet: A single-line, bank-style checkout system has given Whole Foods one of the fastest grocery store lines in New York.
articles.abstract: A single-line, bank-style checkout system has given Whole Foods one of the fastest grocery store lines in New York.
articles.lead_paragraph: Show New Yorkers a checkout line and they’ll tell you whether it’s worth the wait.

articles.headline: Influx From Zimbabwe to South Africa Tests Both
articles.snippet: Zimbabwe’s population is falling as its economy fails, and South Africans face new competition for jobs and housing.
articles.abstract: Zimbabwe’s population is falling as its economy fails, and South Africans face new competition for jobs and housing.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, June 22  As Zimbabwe’s disintegration gathers potentially unstoppable momentum, a swelling tide of migrants is moving into neighboring South Africa, driven into exile by oppression, unemployment and inflation so relentless that many goods now double in price weekly.

articles.headline: Dubai Government Buys Barneys for $825 Million
articles.snippet: The clothing retailer was sold to Istithmar, the investment arm of the Dubai government.
articles.abstract: The clothing retailer was sold to Istithmar, the investment arm of the Dubai government.
articles.lead_paragraph: The clothing retailer Barneys New York, a temple to fashion that introduced Americans to Armani and $300 T-shirts, was sold yesterday to the investment arm of the Dubai government for $825 million.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: General’s Iraq Progress Report Has Competition
articles.snippet: The Bush administration will seek a range of views beyond the report by the U.S. commander in Iraq.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration will seek a range of views beyond the report by the U.S. commander in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23 — Last month, Congress set a deadline for the American commander in Iraq, declaring that by Sept. 15 he would have to assess progress there before billions more dollars are approved to finance the military effort to stabilize the country. The commander, Gen. David H. Petraeus, said in recent days that his report would be only a snapshot of trends, strongly suggesting he will be asking for more time.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Who Might Escape Bausch Without a Scratch?
articles.snippet: The impending sale of Bausch & Lomb has convinced some that the incentive for executives to boost share price has been replaced by a temptation to score huge personal windfalls.
articles.abstract: The impending sale of Bausch & Lomb has convinced some that the incentive for executives to boost share price has been replaced by a temptation to score huge personal windfalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS befits the boss of America’s best-known contact lens maker, Ronald L. Zarrella, the chief executive of Bausch & Lomb, has always had a keen eye for the fine print.

articles.headline: When Models Misbehave
articles.snippet: A move by Bear Stearns to shore up one of its two faltering hedge funds did little to instill confidence in an already fearful market.
articles.abstract: A move by Bear Stearns to shore up one of its two faltering hedge funds did little to instill confidence in an already fearful market.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH Bear Stearns announced on Friday that it would shore up one of its two faltering hedge funds that are heavily exposed to the subprime mortgage mess, the move did little to instill confidence in an already fearful market.

articles.headline: Iran Cracks Down on Dissent
articles.snippet: Facing internal and external problems, the hard-line administration of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has resorted to harsh measures.
articles.abstract: Facing internal and external problems, the hard-line administration of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has resorted to harsh measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iran is in the throes of one of its most ferocious crackdowns on dissent in years, with the government focusing on labor leaders, universities, the press, women’s rights advocates, a former nuclear negotiator and Iranian-Americans, three of whom have been in prison for more than six weeks.

articles.headline: In a World on the Move, a Tiny Land Strains to Cope
articles.snippet: The West African nation of Cape Verde, where almost everyone has a relative abroad,  is a microcosm of the forces of migration that are remaking societies across the globe.
articles.abstract: The West African nation of Cape Verde, where almost everyone has a relative abroad,  is a microcosm of the forces of migration that are remaking societies across the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINDELO, Cape Verde — Virtually every aspect of global migration can be seen in this tiny West African nation, where the number of people who have left approaches the number who remain and almost everyone has a close relative in Europe or America.

articles.headline: Training for the Twists of Driving a School Bus
articles.snippet: A program in Brooklyn helps low-income or unemployed New York City residents become bus or truck drivers.
articles.abstract: A program in Brooklyn helps low-income or unemployed New York City residents become bus or truck drivers.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNTIL recently, Sandra Castillo, 37, a laid-off factory worker, had never driven anything larger than a car. But now she was at the wheel of a 30-foot-long school bus. She made a tight right turn from a wide avenue into a narrow side street in Brooklyn as smoothly as a veteran bus driver.

articles.headline: The Florsheims, Back in Their Own Shoes
articles.snippet: The resurrection of Florsheim sheds light on the fragility of family succession and control in even the most established of enterprises.
articles.abstract: The resurrection of Florsheim sheds light on the fragility of family succession and control in even the most established of enterprises.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF a death notice had been drafted for the Florsheim Group in 2001, the year that the company went on life support, it might have read something like this:

articles.headline: Murdoch, Ruler of a Vast Empire, Reaches Out for Even More
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch’s vast media holdings give him a gamut of tools to enhance his financial interests.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s vast media holdings give him a gamut of tools to enhance his financial interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Jo Becker, Richard Siklos, Jane Perlez and Raymond Bonner, and written by Ms. Becker.

articles.headline: Hussein Cousin Sentenced to Die for Kurd Attacks
articles.snippet: A judge gave five death sentences to the man known as Chemical Ali for his role in gas attacks on Kurdish villagers, but Iraqi interest in the trials has flagged.
articles.abstract: A judge gave five death sentences to the man known as Chemical Ali for his role in gas attacks on Kurdish villagers, but Iraqi interest in the trials has flagged.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, June 24 — As the judge pronounced five death sentences on the man Iraqis know as Chemical Ali, the defendant seemed on Sunday to be a shadow of the merciless enforcer who oversaw poison gas attacks that killed thousands of Kurdish villagers in Iraq’s northern uplands nearly 20 years ago.

articles.headline: At Home Depot, How Green Is That Chainsaw?
articles.snippet: Some environmentalists say that Home Depot is being too inclusive in its new Eco Options marketing campaign.
articles.abstract: Some environmentalists say that Home Depot is being too inclusive in its new Eco Options marketing campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Home Depot sent a note a few months ago to the companies that supply the 176,000 products it sells, inviting them to make a pitch to have their products included in its new Eco Options marketing campaign.

articles.headline: Say ‘Cheese’ for the King of the A-List
articles.snippet: Jason Binn will announce this week that his magazine company, Niche Media, will merge with Greenspun Media Group of Las Vegas, creating a network of 16 publications.
articles.abstract: Jason Binn will announce this week that his magazine company, Niche Media, will merge with Greenspun Media Group of Las Vegas, creating a network of 16 publications.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is easy to underestimate Jason Binn. He practically invites it. An antic, smallish guy with one hand on a BlackBerry and the other on a digital camera, he is constantly roaming parties for his gossamer magazines like Gotham and Los Angeles Confidential, emitting a laugh that brings to mind nothing so much as Woody Woodpecker.

articles.headline: Sales Chief Is the Latest to Depart From Yahoo
articles.snippet: Yahoo said Sunday that Wenda Harris Millard, its longtime chief sales officer, is leaving amid a reorganization of Yahoo’s sales team.
articles.abstract: Yahoo said Sunday that Wenda Harris Millard, its longtime chief sales officer, is leaving amid a reorganization of Yahoo’s sales team.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yahoo said Sunday that Wenda Harris Millard, its longtime chief sales officer, is leaving amid a reorganization of Yahoo’s sales team.

articles.headline: National Lampoon Stakes Revival on Making Own Films
articles.snippet: National Lampoon, once a comedic standard-bearer, will again make original films, including the first one it has produced in 18 years, “National Lampoon’s Bag Boy.”
articles.abstract: National Lampoon, once a comedic standard-bearer, will again make original films, including the first one it has produced in 18 years, “National Lampoon’s Bag Boy.”
articles.lead_paragraph: “Did you say ‘over?’ ” the character played by John Belushi asked in “National Lampoon’s Animal House” in 1978. “Nothing’s over till we decide it is! Was it over when the Germans bombed Pearl Harbor? Hell, no!”

articles.headline: The Web Site Celebrities Fear
articles.snippet: While networks tussled over which would land the first interview with Paris Hilton after her release from jail, the upstart Web site TMZ.com was breaking most of the news.
articles.abstract: While networks tussled over which would land the first interview with Paris Hilton after her release from jail, the upstart Web site TMZ.com was breaking most of the news.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 24 — While the networks tussled over which would land the first interview with Paris Hilton after her release from jail, the upstart Web site TMZ.com was breaking most of the news.

articles.headline: High-Tech Titans Strike Out on Immigration Bill
articles.snippet: Technology executives are trying to shape the Senate immigration bill to meet their demand for foreign workers, but they have had only limited success.
articles.abstract: Technology executives are trying to shape the Senate immigration bill to meet their demand for foreign workers, but they have had only limited success.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24 — Bill Gates and Steven A. Ballmer of Microsoft have led a parade of high-tech executives to Capitol Hill, urging lawmakers to provide more visas for temporary foreign workers and permanent immigrants who can fill critical jobs.

articles.headline: Hollywood Seeks Ways to Fit Its Content Into the Realm of the iPhone
articles.snippet: In Hollywood, media executives are eagerly preparing for a new era as they hope to position more content where consumers want it: in their hands.
articles.abstract: In Hollywood, media executives are eagerly preparing for a new era as they hope to position more content where consumers want it: in their hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 24 — The iPhone doesn’t go on sale until Friday, but Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, is already changing the perception of the mobile phone, from a quick way to call a friend to a hip, media-friendly device. In doing so, he has forced mobile phone and Hollywood executives to react by chasing hungrily after the newest thing or face being left behind.

articles.headline: Waiter, There’s Deer in My Sushi
articles.snippet: Japanese chefs are considering extreme alternatives as shortages of tuna threaten to remove it from sushi menus.
articles.abstract: Japanese chefs are considering extreme alternatives as shortages of tuna threaten to remove it from sushi menus.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, June 24 — Sushi made with deer meat, anyone? How about a slice of raw horse on that rice?
